fullreview: Wonderful for those who love the East and is in Thailand to come to absolutely see wat po and reclining buddha . Enchanting and mystical at the same time. I was out of breath all the time of the visit. Recommended
We went and saw the reclining Buddha but fortunately i went to Myanamar this year as well and their reclining buddha is a lot better, there were a lot of posts here blocking the view
Loved this place. Need 1.5 to 2 hours to visit this place. Take a lot of pictures of the Sleeping Buddha
I've never seen soo many Buddha's before but it was a beautiful sight. interior artwork was stunning and there are set areas where you can relax and meditate.

We actually ended up here in error, we were supposed to be going to grand place. Place is worth a visit mosaics and gold work really good. How did they build these things all those years ago. A definite must do.

quote: An oasis of calm and peace
fullreview: An awesome rendition of Gautam Buddha in a reclining position. The magnificence of the architectural work is something to be experienced. We found it so peaceful and calming.

Not everything you see can be captured on a camera. And this place probably tops that. Hey don’t worry, you have your imagination to capture this beautiful pose of the Buddha. The reclining Buddha is so peaceful and the setting serene, so soak in the feeling. Don’t miss out the paintings in front of the Buddha.This temple complex has so many interesting sights including the towering structures scattered around. Another interesting exhibit is the boards set up around the hall of Buddhas. Each board has “When Thais look at Asians” the perception/opinion of other Asians. This makes an interesting visit for youngsters and the adults alike.

quote: Never belive. Say yes, and then confirm.
fullreview: Very men told us the palace in that day was close. But I already knew it is not true, they want to propose ohters circuits.

We went one morning with our 1 year old and we were pleasantly surprised with the beautiful architecture. It was as well a prettty big temple, bigger than we expected. The Buddha it self was very stunning. I think it's definitely worth a trip

quote: Must see ..when u r in Bangkok
fullreview: I initially thought of visiting 3 - 4 temples in Bangkok, but considering the hot and humid weather, i dropped the idea and to see only This one Wat Pho.. This is a beautiful temple, intricate carvings, gardens adorn this place. it took us about an hour or 2 to complete, especially because me and my husband tried the traditional Thai massage inside the campus of Wat Pho- starts from 250 baht . Also there are several temples inside the campus, if you directly go and see only the reclining Buddha, then you will be done quickly..Overall it was a good experience.
there a big Buddha sleep in the landmark of bangkok near the palace, If you go to the palace you should go to this temple too.
Due to the demise of the King, we had only entry to Reclining budda temple and Wat Arun. This is an excellent architecture.Must visit if you come to Grand Palace area.

Wat Pho, also spelt Wat Po, is a Buddhist temple complex in the Phra Nakhon District, Bangkok, Thailand. It is on Rattanakosin Island, directly south of the Grand Palace. arge landmark temple offering serene grounds with a giant reclining Buddha, historic art & statues.
We visited here street the Grand Palace and was a lovely chilled out Wat. Reclining buddha was very impressive and surrounding areas. So glad we checked it out.
Undergoing some renovation, but still definitely worth the visit. Prayer vessels for coins along the "backside corridor are interesting.
Very interesting nice place well kept and typical Thai hospitalityClose to Grand Palace also....................

This was one of the highlights of my trip. I was planning a visit on my previous trip to Bangkok but could not make it. This time round made sure it was on my itinerary. Amazing place, so serene and peaceful. Spiritually uplifting.
I went there so quite and nice place, free mineral water per one ticket :) so clean and well organized
Fantastic and awe inspiring. Beautiful reclining Buddha. Be sure to go during the least crowded times or you won't get to see it

Worth a visit for sure. The fee to enter is very nominal and this is just around the corner from the Grand Palace. They close at 6:30 pm but we didn't arrive until 6:20 and were quickly able to walk the grounds for another hour.
there a big Buddha sleep in the landmark of bangkok near the palace, If you go to the palace you should go to this temple too.
Due to the demise of the King, we had only entry to Reclining budda temple and Wat Arun. This is an excellent architecture.Must visit if you come to Grand Palace area.

Wat Pho, also spelt Wat Po, is a Buddhist temple complex in the Phra Nakhon District, Bangkok, Thailand. It is on Rattanakosin Island, directly south of the Grand Palace. arge landmark temple offering serene grounds with a giant reclining Buddha, historic art & statues.
We visited here street the Grand Palace and was a lovely chilled out Wat. Reclining buddha was very impressive and surrounding areas. So glad we checked it out.
Undergoing some renovation, but still definitely worth the visit. Prayer vessels for coins along the "backside corridor are interesting.
Very interesting nice place well kept and typical Thai hospitalityClose to Grand Palace also....................

This was one of the highlights of my trip. I was planning a visit on my previous trip to Bangkok but could not make it. This time round made sure it was on my itinerary. Amazing place, so serene and peaceful. Spiritually uplifting.
I went there so quite and nice place, free mineral water per one ticket :) so clean and well organized
Fantastic and awe inspiring. Beautiful reclining Buddha. Be sure to go during the least crowded times or you won't get to see it

Worth a visit for sure. The fee to enter is very nominal and this is just around the corner from the Grand Palace. They close at 6:30 pm but we didn't arrive until 6:20 and were quickly able to walk the grounds for another hour.
the buddha is not too unique but the size makes it pretty amazing! It's nearby so you should go but don't go out of your way to see this.

This is one of the places i would recommend which is a must see. The entry is nominal and affordable. Do not miss. You can view the reclining Buddha at its supreme and other structures inside the premises. Small souvenir shops and ice-cream shops. Try them . You can spend two hours. The entry is 100 baht. Please Carry water. It was hot in Nov also. Please be covered on shoulders and legs.
very impressive - definitely worth visiting, although can be crowded. allow a few hours for the visit.
I was with my family to see the beautiful temple. incredible beauty in thailand raccomended. fixed stop there

quote: Must visited place near Grand Palace area
fullreview: Located near Grand Palace area..you just walk away from Grand Palace. And when you will go to Wat Arun, just pass using ferry boat service accross Chao Phraya rive

quote: A change from the usual Buddha statue
fullreview: This Buddha sleeps.... and is probably the most accurate description of a Thai person, as all they seem to do is sleep. On the trains, buses etc!! ;-) This is a nice temple to wander around, and from memory you can arrive by vehicle or boat on the river.
Before 32 years visited this place but have no memory,this visit really worth for me.dont remember exactly whether things changed or not !
Love the architechure of the building and admire on how they preserve the Buddha statues throughout the years. But, there are some ignorant tourist who play the offering throughout my visit.

This was one of our top places to visit on our recent trip to Bangkok. We reached it by river ferry and a local shopkeeper even gave us tickets to get in when we bought some drinks from him. The main attraction is the massive reclining golden Buddha and that on its own was well worth visiting. The temple complex is vast and there is so much to see that it can't really be achieved in a single visit, if it is hot and it was. I have an interest in sculptures and artwork so that was what I looked for and there are some impressive small and large sculptures to be seen. Some of the gate guardians are really impressive.Overall one of our top places that we visited that give you an idea of the culture and religion of Thailand.
Must watch when you travel to Bangkok. I have never seen such a big and beautiful statue in my life.

We loved our visit to the Reclining Buddha, the Temple is serene and so beautiful. We went on a Thursday and it was less busy than the other Temples we visited in Bankok. The size and detail of the Buddha are very impressive. It is a "can't miss" temple in Bangkok .

I visited this temple with my family on a private guided tour. We really enjoyed having a guide for ourselves (we where a small group with 4 adults and 2 small kids). Even the kids found it impressive to see this large Buddha.I highly recommend having a guided while visiting here as there is so much history you would otherwise miss.

quote: A must to visit in Bangkok
fullreview: This temple is something else, its more like an old village with lot of beautiful history. Can be crowd special on weekends.

Wat Pho !!!One of the Top 10 places to Visit in Bangkok!Situated in Old main city, need 3 to 4 hours if you want to completely appreciate the beauty of the place.This place has got such a Devine power that you will feel the spiritual peace all by yourself.The Reclining Buddha statue is too BIG, more than you can imagine.Important points :Entrance Fee : THB 100 / person Dress Code - Decent mandatoryWater - Arrangement available by Chang and free bottle with each ticket.Time - Must start early to avoid rush and easy picture opportunities...Go Get the Blessing of Buddha !!!
I enjoyed visiting this place. I would suggest getting their early at the line builds up. Avoid local translators as they may be pricy but you can bargain down to 60%
Very impressive Tempel, not only the Buddha itself. The entire Temple with all ist side Tempels, Stuppas etc.
Brought here by our guide Mandy from Mandy Smile Guide, we had a enjoyable visit. The reclining Buddha is very long.
The laying Buddha is good, Worth go there because is impressive. Around we can see many nice places like temple and Buddha statues and learn a little bit about the history.

A nice place to visit for sure, if not just to check it off the list. Nice sights but in fact it looks better on the promotional photos that in reality.You may spend few hours here, but just as well you can get a full scope of it in under an hour, your choice.

Visited this temple in the morning but it was still fairly busy. You also get a free bottle of water with your ticket.Remember to dress appropriately when visiting any temple. The sheer size of the reclining Buddha is breathtaking and worth the visit.

Went there as a part of the city tour. Nothing great to talk about but should not miss it. At the most could spend half an hour to 45 mins there. Being humid at day's time should carry drinking water and some eatables.
Highly recommended, very near to Grand Palace too. A great place to pray and one of the largest reclining buddha in Bangkok. There are other temples within the premises too.
Went to see with my family Fantastic day it really is fantastic a must to see on a visit to BangkokAllow a good 4 hours so many other attractions to seeAnd very near china town for lunch Mike
The reclining Buddha was huge. Many tourist but it's very well organised. A must see place! Oh.... do try the local fruits.
Excellent monument. Must see . 100bht entry fees for all. It is beside the King palace.10 mins walk

Needless to say, this is one of the most important sites in Bangkok. It may be helpful to know, however, that this is a complex of many temples and can take quite some time to visit. You may not want to see every single building, so acquaint yourself with the layout and visit those areas that you most wish to see first. If you get tired, you can skip out on the rest as it is so easy to get burnt out seeing temple after temple in Thailand.

The temple has a lot of Buddha idolsThree main idols areReclining Buddha: Very huge!Standing BuddhaSitting BuddhaYou can spend a good 1 hr. Price is 100 THB per personHowever, please do not use tour guide. The charges are 200 THB per person which is a lot. You can find a temple map inside which would provide you with sufficient detailsAlso there are some free relaxing massage services, some yoga etc available in temple premises

One of the best tourist spots in Bangkok. Very calm serene and has a lot of temples to visit. Probably the temple authorities can give some sort of flyers explaining the layout and significance of various spots of significant inside the temple
Well maintained temple. Our trip to temple was good s the temple was not too crowded n v cud pray well
Although the crowds do get very busy at times, if you can block them out you can't help but feel the purpose and meaning of this statue.

Impressive temple full of alleys and buildings where you can find The Reclined Budha. You can't miss this attraction in Bangkok.The best way to get there is by boat, since the traffic in Bangkok is very heavy in rush hours.Don't miss this tour.
The second most important (after Emerald Buddha) Buddha statue in Bangkok. Impressive, yet calming place. Entrance fee quite high (100 THB) when comparing to other places.

Wat Pho or Wat Phra Chetuphon Wimonmangkalaram also known as he Temple of the Reclining Buddha.largest reclining gold plated buddha it is also the oldest wat and learning center in Bangkok. It's located very close to the Grand Palace and across the river from Wat Arun. A place Must to visit
A grand temple off of the river. Do bring change to leave the proper honorifics and you pass the stations around the reclining Buddha.
Don't miss this temple while being in Bangkok. The reclining Buddha is an enormous and impressive construction. You can walk around and visit the different sites for at least 2 hours.

quote: Wonderful experience within the Wat Pho Temple
fullreview: The Wat Pho is a beautiful temple in Bangkok with the main attraction being the huge reclining Buddha.Other than that there are other temples within the premise of different Buddha statues and its very peaceful and serene. The architecture of the temple is lovely and the premises are kept very clean.
This is a beautiful Royal Temple Complex , a must -see place for all first time visitors to Bangkok. The entry fee was 100 bahts , and one can spend around 2-3 hours here.
very nice place, and a must see. went from hotel (Shangri-La) by the boat, and went back by tuk-tuk.
This is a must visit when in BKK. Easily accessible by boat from the Sathorn pier and very close to the Grand Palace. Do ignore the tuktuk drivers who insist that the temple is closed.
This place always reminds me the past and rethink what people would be on that time.Note: You should go there properly dress as a respect to their God.No shorts and sleeveless.
It is very nice a lot of buddhas around but as the time goes by it starts to get a little boring so I would not recommend to stay longer than 2 hours.

We had a guide for afternoon and visited the golden Buddha and the reclining Buddha and then went on a small boat trip. It was really enjoyable and educational. The guide we had was very knowledgeable and we could ask lots of questions as his English was faultless.
No big crowd during our visit on the 17th Oct which suited us well as we have 2 young children with us. Interesting . Traffic was quite bad , jam around the temple area when we left at noon.

location: Ras Al Khaimah, United Arab Emirates
fullreview: Incredible not to be missed temple in Bangkok, actually a lot nicer than the palace and cheaper and easier to get into. Highly recommended.

Crowded... victim of its own success... Furthermore never forget that: it's a holy temple !With packing crowd and stifling heat, you must take a lot of time to fulfill your visit... And you have a lot to see (inside, outside, etc.)Otherwise very cheap, around 3 euros for adult only.

So huge is the Reclining Buddha that one feels scared in the first, but when I looked at him the almighty is blessings the mankind.The place is very peaceful, immediately you feel the mind has been purified and the size seems to be indicative of him giving us protection..Truly a touch of divinity...

You would have to walk a bit to cover the whole area. But its worth the walk. Every corner of this temple is worth watching. Do not miss this place if you are in Bangkok and interested in Buddhist temples.

quote: this is an amazing feat of engineering and a beautiful palace
fullreview: definitely try to to get there as early as possible or later in the afternoon...the crazy tour buses show up and thousands pour our and are pushy and rude. the palace, if you get away from the reclining Buddha is very serene and you almost have it to yourself!!

quote: A Large and Beautiful Piece of Fine Arts
fullreview: The most interesting temple visit during my Bangkok trip, near the entrance exhibits the history of the temples, directories and inscriptions of Wat Pho. The temple area is big and it consist some small temples. The reclining Buddha is the largest and a beautiful piece of fine arts of Buddha's image in a reclining position. Located just beside the Grand Palace. Definitely worth a visit.
The place was for buddhist people go to pray the buddhist day ,had many Buddha seat a link not many tourist only Thia local.

Wat Pho in the eye of a spiritual traveler.Beyond the mundane lies the spiritual bliss present within.The Buddha represents to many an enlighten being who has awakened to his true spiritual essence. In the Hindu Vaishnav tradition he is an Avatar of the Divine himself , Krishna ( one of the ten avatars).The reclining Buddha is not resting but rather meditating and resemble to some extend Lord Vishnu who is reclining on the Shesa Naga ( serpent) while countless universes emerges from his naval.This could be a place of worship of you came in that mind set.You may light a candle and offer intense and a lotus bud and offer gold leaves to be placed on small scale Buddhas at the entrance You may also place 108 coins in the 108 bowels behind the Buddha for spiritual purification ( 108 to resemble the 108 chakras on your spine and the 1008 lotus petals on your crown).You may also choose to donate a box set ( filled with the essential monk needs) for a monk (1,000 bhat) and receive a blessing. It could be a day of contemplation and meditation beyond merely a tourist attraction , and then again it is entirely up to you.Enjoy
Went there with whole family. Everyone love this lovely and old temple. Feel lot of calmness and inner peace at this place.
The structure of the temple is simply amazing. Plus, the washroom is clean. Not like what I have expected it to be.
A must visit place if your are interested in exploring the cultural aspect of thailand. just sit and close your eyes for a few minutes near the recycling buddha.

quote: One of the more interesting temples- visit by water
fullreview: Lot's of visitors to Bangkok are templed-out. Understandable. I particularly enjoyed Wat Pho. The reclining buddha is unique and impressive. It is enjoyably reachable by water boat (the local ferry is much more economical than the tourist boat and affords the same view and ride). The grounds of the temple are beautiful . Not many explore all of the hidden corners, a walk around is worthwhile. The grounds also host a massage school and I've heard the massages are excellent although unfortunately I didn't have the opportunity to sample them myself.

Bangkok is a place where so many Buddha's Temples.From that " Reclining Buddhas " is one ofThe most & must visited place by Tourist.This is really different place from other Temples.Click the pictures for good memories.Transport is " tuk tuk" as we say rickshaw.by train& by taxi or car.  Take Anyway of mode ,but must see it.
Very exquisite place Lots of Thai decor. Retains a mystical presence. Many selfies being taken I wonder if they felt the mysticism very powerful icon of Buddhist faith

This is another wonderful temple and must visit place in Bangkok .. the sleeping or reclining Buddha is awesome and must visit to take blessings .. calm and relax face of Buddha gives the Devine peace . .. wonderful architecture all across and maintain nicely ..

Amazing old temple to visit and its magnificent reclining Buddha really attract people to do selfies which created long queue from the entrance. I think you'd better visit this place in the early morning before crowed.
The statue is impressive but the temple complex is amazing in its own right. Make time to wander and see the standing image and enjoy peaceful courtyards.

There are many Buddha's and temples in Thailand, but this is one that you don't want to miss. The reclining Buddha is impressive not only for its setting in the large temple but for the size and craftsmanship. Standing near the reclining Buddha you are dwarfed by this immense statue. Pictures nor words so this do this justice. Visiting the temples in Thailand you, ladies you will need to cover your legs (no shorts) they do provide sarongs. Don't forget to buy the coins so that you can spread your wishes and prayers that run along the entire wall of the reclining Buddha. The kids were impressed and really enjoyed the visit.
Inspite of the crowds, the Temple people made sure the flow of people around the Buddha was smooth. The Buddha is a "must see".
This is an impressive site with beautiful buildings and architecture. It would be nice if there was some sort of English guide or map, we never received one.
Went this place twice during both my trip to BKK. Always learning something new out of this place. Worth the visit here
amazing place to visit we were amazed to see the orderliness and display of heritage and cultural wealth

quote: Unusual and well worth a visit
fullreview: The reclining Buddha is unusual and well worth a stop. The statuary is huge. The most valuable tip I can offer for visiting temples in Bangkok is not to go by car, the traffic can clog bumper to bumper. Rather take a river boat in which you can get on and get off at most of the main attractions.

Neat, cleanly maintained. Interior areas of temple are peaceful. It reflects the Thai tradition and ancient buddhist cluture. The statue of reclining buddha is magnificent and this is a must visit place to know about traditional values and culture of Thailand and especially to appreciate the famous ancient Thai architecture

It is just behind Grand Palace and around 12 minutes walking distance. As we were with children took a tuk tuk with 35 bhat. There are hundred of buddha statues with the one big buddha in a sleeping state. Worth a visit. You can also come 5hrough the river route also. 10 minutes walk from ferry station.

I have to say wow! What a breathtaking monument. It seems separated from the world outside. Situated near the grand palace and has lot to offer. Make sure you spend at least a few hours going through the yard in order to see the whole ground. By the way if you enter through the South Gate you don't have to pay twice.
A short distance from the king palace, this temple is much simpler to visit, the statue is huge around 50 meters.really impressive and great to take photos.
